newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- MARCH 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- MARCH 13.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--A night of crisis in Tirana as the airport closes and the fighting moves closer to the capital. There were reports of street fighting in Korce. New Prime Minister Bashkim Fino said earlier yesterday that he wanted dialogue and to speak to leaders of rebels in Gjirokaster and called for the immediate release of jailed Socialist leader Fatos Nano.

--Prime Minister Costas Simitis yesterday expressed his fears of a spread of the crisis to other Balkan nations. Foreign Minister Theodoros Pangalos and Deputy Foreign Minister Yannos Kranidiotis will fly to Tirana tomorrow for talks with all parties.
--Western capitals are promoting a face-to-face dialogue between Cypriot President Glafcos Clerides and Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash.

--The environment, town planning and public works ministry has turned to the private sector for additional financing of the Egnatia Highway and the Patras-Evzones highway. An added attraction will be the ability to charge tolls on parts of the roads.

--Sacrifices are necessary for Greece to achieve convergence, the prime minister says. He appeared unmovable in the face of continued demands by strikers, saying if the government conceded, Greece would lose.
--The noose around Tirana tightens and Albanian President Sali Berisha reportedly arms his supporters while new prime minister Fino makes overtures to rebels.

--Pangalos and Kranidiotis in Tirana tomorrow for their mediation efforts to avert a civil war in the neighbouring country. Greek diplomats are already meeting with representatives of the rebels to lay the ground for tomorrow's meeting.
--There are no margins for any further handouts to strikers, Prime Minister Simitis stressed last night.

--The four challengers for the leadership of conservative opposition New Democracy agreed yesterday on a number of points regarding the party's charter: the countdown to the crucial party congress now begins in earnest.
--Substantial changes are planned to appointments to the civil service, with more emphasis placed on the written examination, to be held every year. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
